header.title: LIBER LXXXIV [CHANOKH] SUB FIGURA LXXXIV
header.category: Western Esotericism, Enochian Magic, Occultism, Grimoire Tradition

central_thesis: The central thesis is to present a structured, symbolic, and operative system for interacting with angelic and elemental intelligences, derived from the scrying sessions of John Dee and Edward Kelly. It aims to represent the universe in a four-dimensional symbolic model, providing the names, sigils, and invocations necessary to access and manipulate its elemental and spiritual components for practical magical work, with interpretations and expansions by later occultists, notably Aleister Crowley.

structure_content.chapter_title: PART I: THE SYMBOLIC REPRESENTATION OF THE UNIVERSE
structure_content.summary: This section introduces the foundational components of the Enochian magical system, detailing the Holy Table, the Sigillum Dei Æmeth, the Holy Sevenfold Table with names of God and Angels, and the Four Great Watch-Towers attributed to the elements. It explains the derivation of various angelic and elemental names (e.g., Filiæ Lucis, Elemental Kings, Seniors, Kerubim) from the intricate grids of letters on these tables, often through specific diagonal or linear readings. It also outlines the hierarchical attributions of squares within the tables to Sephiroth, Planets, Zodiacal signs, and Tarot cards, providing the cosmological framework for the practical operations.

structure_content.chapter_title: V: The Thirty Æthyrs or Aires
structure_content.summary: This part details the hierarchical structure of the thirty spiritual 'Æthyrs' or 'Aires' that encompass the mundane world. Each Æthyr is enumerated and associated with specific 'Governors' (Angels) and their corresponding 'Numbers of Servitors.' Plate X visually represents the unique sigils or paths for each of these Governors as traced upon the Great Table of Watchtowers, offering a practical key for their invocation and interaction within the system. It also identifies the sigils for the four Great Elemental Kings derived from the corners of this comprehensive table.

structure_content.chapter_title: PART II: THE FORTY-EIGHT KEYS OR CALLS
structure_content.summary: This section provides the practical invocations, known as the 'Forty-Eight Keys or Calls,' in the Enochian (Angelic) language, accompanied by their English translations. It outlines the specific use and scope of each of the initial 18 (effectively 19) Keys, indicating which parts of the magical system they activate (e.g., Tablet of Union, specific Watchtowers or elemental angles). It includes instructions for 'The Opening of the Portal of the Vault of the Adepts' and 'The Opening of the Temple' at various A∴A∴ grades, specifying required signs, divine names, invoking pentagrams/hexagrams, and magical tools. It also presents the general 'Call or Key of the Thirty Æthyrs' for traversing these planes and the three 'Mighty Names of God' derived from them.

This crucial section provides comprehensive academic and practical commentary on the text, addressing its publication history, the incompleteness of Crowley's edition, and the integration of Dee's original work with later Golden Dawn interpretations. It highlights textual variations between different source manuscripts (e.g., Dee's MSS, Casaubon, Equinox) and offers corrections to diagrams and names. Crucially, it discusses Enochian pronunciation rules, the derivation of names, and the attributions of calls to tables, emphasizing the complexities and potential deviations from Dee's original angelic system.

key_concepts.definition: The central ritual furnishing, a physical representation of the macrocosm, upon which the Sigillum Dei Æmeth is placed, and around which seven planetary talismans and the Holy Twelvefold Table are arranged, acting as the foundation for all angelic operations.

The 'Seal of God's Truth,' a complex circular diagram with intricate geometry, Hebrew, and Enochian lettering, placed upon the Holy Table. It serves as a microcosmic map of divine and angelic hierarchies, a focus for skrying, and the source for various angelic names and powers.

Four large elemental tablets (East/Air, West/Water, North/Earth, South/Fire) which form the boundaries of the Enochian Great Table. Each is a grid composed of Enochian letters and symbols, from which specific divine, angelic, and elemental names are systematically derived for invocation, representing the elemental divisions of the universe.

A central tablet attributed to the element of Spirit, conceived as geometrically uniting the four Watch-Towers. Its letters are used in specific operations to generate divine names that rule lesser parts of the system and to understand the underlying unity of the elemental realms.

A hierarchical system of 30 increasingly subtle spiritual regions or 'Aires' that emanate from the divine and surround the physical world. Each Æthyr is governed by specific 'Governors' (Angels) and legions of 'Servitors,' invoked to gain knowledge, power, or to travel to these spiritual planes.

A collection of 19 (functionally 18) primary invocations in the Enochian Language, followed by 30 specific calls for the Æthyrs. These are 'Most Solemn Invocations,' used to open the various parts of the magical system and conjure the intelligences associated with the Tablets and Æthyrs.

The 'Angelic Language' or 'Elemental Language' revealed to John Dee and Edward Kelly through skrying. It is considered a language of power, with its own alphabet, grammar, and pronunciation rules (sometimes interpreted through Golden Dawn phonetics), essential for all invocations within this system.

key_concepts.term: Linea Patris, Linea Filii, Linea Spiritus Sancti
key_concepts.definition: Specific conceptual lines or 'files' within the Watch-Towers from which names of divine and angelic intelligences are extracted. These correspond to Qabalistic or Thelemic concepts representing the 'Father,' 'Son,' and 'Holy Spirit' principles within the elemental hierarchy.

Smaller crosses of ten squares found within each sub-elemental Tablet (e.g., Air of Air). These crosses are central to generating names for Kerubim and other mighty benevolent angels, as well as trilateral names for lesser elementals or demons, guiding the hierarchy of invocation for more specific magical operations.

practical_system.description: The system described in Liber LXXXIV is a ceremonial magical framework for establishing communication and interaction with a hierarchy of angelic and elemental intelligences. It is based on a four-dimensional symbolic representation of the universe, primarily depicted through the Holy Table, the Sigillum Dei Æmeth, the Four Great Watch-Towers (representing elemental realms), and the Thirty Æthyrs (representing spiritual planes). Operations involve ritually deriving and invoking specific divine, angelic, and elemental names by tracing paths and extracting letters from the intricate grids of these tables according to precise rules, ultimately aiming to manifest their powers or gain secret knowledge.
tools: Shew-stone (Scrying Crystal): The primary instrument for receiving angelic communications and for visual projection during Æthyr workings.
Holy Table: The central ritual altar, often constructed with specific wood and dimensions, upon which other ritual items are placed.
Sigillum Dei Æmeth: The intricate wax seal, engraved with divine and angelic names, placed atop the Holy Table as a focal point for angelic contact.
Four Great Watch-Towers (Tablets): Physical or diagrammatic representations of the elemental realms, forming the core grids for name extraction and invocation.
Black Cross (Tablet of Union): A central tablet, typically represented as a grid of letters, for deriving specific names and understanding the unity of the elemental forces.
Enochian Alphabet: The unique script for transcribing and correctly vibrating the Angelic Language during invocations.

Magical Weapons: Elemental tools such as the air-dagger (for Air), cup (for Water), censer (for Fire), and salt (for Earth), used to direct elemental forces and perform ritual gestures, often consecrated to specific archangels (e.g., Raphael for Air, Gabriel for Water).

Qabalistic and Astrological Knowledge: Essential for correctly interpreting the attributions of squares and angles on the tables to Sephiroth, Planets, Zodiacal signs, and Tarot Trumps, which informs the ritual intent and specific invocations.
rituals: Preparation and Consecration of the Holy Table: Setting up the primary altar with the Sigillum Dei Æmeth, seven planetary talismans, and the Holy Twelvefold Table, establishing a consecrated ritual space.

Elemental Openings and Temple Grades: Performing specific rituals for 'Opening the Temple' corresponding to elemental attributions (Air, Water, Earth, Fire) and A∴A∴ grades (2°=9º, 3°=8º, 1°=10°, 4°=7°). These involve precise signs (e.g., Sign of Shu for Air), adorations of divine names (e.g., Shaddai El Chai), and the use of invoking pentagrams and hexagrams for Spirit and the specific element.

Watchtower Invocations: Utilizing the first 18 'Keys' or 'Calls' to invoke specific angels, elemental kings, and other intelligences associated with the Tablet of Union, the four elemental Watch-Towers, and their sub-elemental angles (e.g., Air of Air, Fire of Water).

Æthyr Invocations: Employing the 30 'Calls of the Æthyrs' to project consciousness, or 'skry,' into the corresponding spiritual planes, invoking their Governors and legions of Servitors for gnosis or influence.

Name Generation and Activation: Systematically extracting and combining letters from the Holy Sevenfold Table, Watch-Towers, and Black Cross to generate specific names for various entities (e.g., Filiæ Lucis, Elemental Kings, Kerubim, 'trilateral names of demons or elementals'), which are then vibrated or used in invocations to call forth or compel these powers.

relevant_quotes.text: The Skryer obtained from certain Angels a series of seven talismans. These, grouped around the Holy Twelvefold Table, similarly obtained, were part of the furniture of the Holy Table, as shown in Plate I., opposite.
Note first the Holy Sevenfold Table containing seven Names of God which not even the Angels are able to pronounce.
Each of these lesser Tablets contains a Calvary Cross of ten squares, which governs it.
These three sets of names rule the whole tablet, and must be invoked before specializing in the lesser angles of the sub-elements.
The Thirty Æthyrs or Aires and their divisions and angels are as follows
These are Most Solemn Invocations. Use these only after other invocations.
Pronounce Elemental language (also called Angelic or Enochian) by inserting the next following Hebrew vowel between consonants, e.g. e after b (bEth), i after g (gImel), a after d, etc.
Every letter in Paraoan is a living fire; but all of one quality and of one creation; But unto N is delivered a viol of Destruction, according to that part that he is of Paraoan the Governour.

critical_analysis.relevance: Liber LXXXIV is a cornerstone text in Western Esotericism, particularly for practitioners of Enochian magic. It offers a unique, albeit partial, glimpse into the complex angelic system revealed to John Dee and Edward Kelly. Its publication by Aleister Crowley integrated this system into Thelemic magical currents, making it a key text in the A∴A∴ curriculum and influencing subsequent occult organizations like the Golden Dawn. The text's detailed schematics of the Watch-Towers, Sigillum Dei Æmeth, and the Calls provide an operative framework for ceremonial magic, though often requiring cross-referencing with other Dee source materials and Golden Dawn interpretations due to its incompleteness and textual variations. It represents a significant historical document of post-Renaissance magical thought and its modern adaptations.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is advanced practitioners of ceremonial magic, particularly those specializing in Enochian and Dee's angelic system. It requires a solid foundation in Qabalistic cosmology (Sephiroth, elements, planets, Zodiac) and the principles of ceremonial magic. The text's dense, technical descriptions, reliance on complex diagrams, and the necessity for precise Enochian pronunciation and ritual execution make it unsuitable for beginners. It is implicitly aimed at magicians seeking direct communication with spiritual intelligences for gnosis, influence, and the practical application of divine and elemental forces within a highly structured cosmological framework.
